awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Climate controls on carbon accumulation in upland permafrost at millennial scales
awd_abstract_narration:
Permafrost, or perennially frozen ground, holds a large reservoir of carbon. The overarching goal of this study is to look to the recent geologic past to improve understanding of how future changes in climate may impact carbon accumulation and release. The investigators have combined expertise in paleoecology, paleoclimatology, surficial geology, geochronology, and quantitiative geomorphology. Together, they will quantify the relationship between climate and the mass of carbon that accumulated under distinctly different climates of the past 40,000 years in hilly upland regions of the Arctic, which will complment previous work on the effects of climate change on permafrost carbon in lakes and peatlands of low-lying terrain. Results will add paleo perspectives to the Permafrost Carbon Network, part of the Study of Environmental Arctic Change. The project will provide training for graduate and undergraduate students, and the team of investigators includes an early career scientist.

In this study, the investigators will combine field-collections, analysis of sediment cores, and modeling to quantify the millennial scale relationship between climate and permafrost carbon accumulation at an upland study site in the Eight Mile Lake watershed in the northern foothills of the Alaska Range. They will take multiple sediment cores along hillslope transects to map the underlying stratigraphic framework; contrast the surficial materials mantling both a short and a long slope to infer the relative roles of slope-length- versus slope-angle-dependent transport processes; and use these data in a numerical model to simulate hillslope evolution and assess downslope geomorphic processes that transfer sediment and sequester carbon. The investigators will also use radiocarbon dating of macrofossils to determine the extent to which organic matter has been stratigraphically mixed and to distninguish millennial-scale periods of accumulation; evaluate pollen and macrofossiles for community characteristics and grain size distributions; and analyze sediment sequences for a suite of bio-physical properties to quantify carbon mass, accumulation, and decomposition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organic-rich surficial materials of the Arctic are a storehouse of frozen carbon of global consequence. How much carbon is amassed by, or released from this reservoir depends on climate on all timescales. Given the complexity of carbon-cycle dynamics in terrain underlain by perennially frozen ground (permafrost), there is considerable uncertainty about the long-term response of underground carbon storage to climate changes. Climate changes that occurred during the recent geologic past address this uncertainty by serving as natural experiments to investigate how climate influences the rate at which carbon is either sequestered within permafrost or exposed to decomposition and released to the atmosphere. This study contributed to understanding the long-term (millennial-scale) relation between climate and the mass of carbon that accumulated under the changing climates of the past 16,000 years, with implications for the permafrost climate feedbacks associated with anthropogenic warming.

This project featured a landscape view of the surficial sediment in an Arctic lake and its watershed, highlighting the variability of the carbon-rich organic matter that it contains. It investigated the extent to which intervals of organic-matter accumulation during the past 16,000 years could be correlated across different depositional settings, including hillslopes, river terraces and a lake bottom. The Eight Mile Lake watershed was chosen as a study site because changes in permafrost carbon storage occurring under recent climate change have been studied extensively in this watershed. In addition, the surficial sediment in the study area is representative of expansive upland regions of Alaska, which represents possibly the least-well known component of the arctic frozen organic carbon inventory. 

This project generated a major dataset of a wide variety of sediment properties measured on hundreds of samples collected in cores from Eight Mile Lake and nearby hillslopes, as well as natural exposures through river terraces. The data were used to quantify the mass of carbon contained in sedimentary organic matter, its rate of net accumulation, and the extent to which it is decomposed. The analyses included geochronology (radiocarbon, lead and cesium, volcanic ash geochemistry), sedimentary physical properties (bulk density, magnetic susceptibility, grain-size distribution), biogeochemical properties (abundance of bulk organic matter, biogenic silica, chlorophyll  pigment, carbon and nitrogen, carbonate, and amino acids), and floral remains (pollen and vegetation macrofossils).

The project provided a unique perspective on watershed-scale carbon cycling. Within the lake, burial rate was the primary control on organic carbon accumulation. Burial by wind-blown sediment (eolian loess) is also critical to sequestering organic carbon on hillslopes and terraces, with more organic matter accumulated along slopes that face into the wind and toward major sources of eolian sediment. Most commonly, the upper 30-50 cm of hillslope surficial material contains the majority of the total carbon inventory. Mixing by freeze–thaw helped to preserve organic carbon deeper into the surficial sediment. Relatively high temperatures during the early stages of hillslope sediment accumulation prior to around 6000 years ago enhanced the degradation of the organic matter. An analysis of the ages of organic material from the study area shows a downturn in the frequency of dated material between 5500 and 3500 years ago, which could reflect reduced productivity associated with Neoglacial cooling.  Neither the stratigraphy nor the ages of buried soils in sedimentary sequences overlying the river terraces are as consistent as portrayed in previous studies. Heterogeneity in the surficial sediment and the organic carbon it contains reflects local influence of topography and vegetation on eolian sediment and organic matter, as well as variable inputs from multiple sediment sources.

This project brought together expertise in arctic paleoecology, paleoclimatology, surficial geology, geochronology and geomorphology. The lake sediment cores are archived at the national lake core facility and are available for future study. The major datasets are available through a portal at the Arctic Data Center devoted to this project and are reported in peer reviewed journal articles. The project supported graduate assistantships for one PhD, two Masters, and four undergraduate students.
